text:
These molecules exist in a virtual world where
chemists can rearrange, bend, and even play
catch with them.

Researchers at the University of Bristol combined
off-the-shelf virtual-reality hardware with

cloud-based molecular simulations to enable
chemists to interact with 3-D molecular models,
like this model of a protein and small molecule.

The technology could help accelerate research
in areas like drug development, synthetic

biology, and catalyst design, the researchers
say.

The system is one of a number of interactive
molecular simulations researchers are developing

to enhance chemistsâ€™ understanding of molecules
in research and education.

Using the VR rig, users can reach out and
grab, twist, and bend simulated molecules
as though they were physical models.

But unlike physical models, the VR system
lets researchers experience how the molecules
actually move and flex in three dimensions.

The team studied how quickly users could complete
tasks using the VR system versus a computer
mouse or touch screen.

They found that after a brief practice period,
testers could complete molecular tasks faster

in the VR environment than by using more conventional
interfaces.

For example, they could tie this knot in a
small protein molecule about ten times faster

using the VR system than by using a computer
mouse.

And the system is multiuser, allowing up to
six users to interact with the same molecule
at once.

Fred Brooks, who was among those who pioneered
earlier immersive molecular modeling technologies,

said he was impressed by the real-time simulation
of molecular forces and motions, as well as
the multiuser capability.

The Bristol team continues to work to improve
the complexity of their simulations, including

by integrating sensory feedback, like sounds
to indicate chemical errors, and developing

technology to bring chemical reactions to
the VR environment.

And the researchers made the program available
so anyone with virtual-reality gear can try
their own molecular simulation.
